awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Non-invasive Neonatal Brainstem Monitoring to Improve Sleep, Minimize Disruptions and Enhance Feeding Stamina Leading to Earlier Discharge and Healthier Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is improved health and lowered cost of care for 15 million babies who are born prematurely or severely underweight each year. These 'premies' require weeks or months of care in specialized hospital units (e.g. NICU). In the United States, a typical NICU stay costs about $80K, and the total cost of healthcare during the first year of life is about $16B annually. These babies are at elevated risk for a range of serious lifelong complications that economically burden society by over $30B. This project has the potential to make a substantial impact to one of the most core vital elements of neonatal growth and development by improving the baby's sleep-wake-feed cycle. Today that cycle is irregular, episodic and disrupted almost 80% of the time which prolongs hospitalization. If successful, this project and technology would provide clinicians with a new tool and approach to help babies establish regularity, build up more energy and take on more calories so they can be discharged 20% faster. More importantly, this technology could lower the rate of downstream neuro developmental complications which are linked directly to poor sleep patterns.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will result in a simple miniature wearable patch and display system that clinicians can use to monitor neonatal sleep and development patterns. This new tool will help clinicians achieve their goals of improving sleep-wake-feed cycles. In Phase I the team developed a prototype sensor configured to work on tiny babies and demonstrated that it could be used to accurately measure sleep cycles. In Phase II, the main objective is to advance the design and performance of this instrument to enable routine reliable use. It should be simple and non-intrusive for any clinician to reliably position the sensor and monitor any baby for multi-day periods. Analysis data should be presented real-time in an easy-to-interpret and actionable format. The work includes further biomedical engineering to improve attachment, amplifier circuit modelling to widen dynamic range and signal processing to automate artifact handling. The team will develop and test machine learning routines that will display detailed accurate and reliable instantaneous and trend data of brainstem-based sleep patterns that are not available today. These new advances, built on novel brainstem biomeasures will open up broad adoption supporting the development of a business and substantial medical advances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Non-invasive Neonatal Brainstem Monitoring to Improve Sleep, Minimize Disruptions and Enhance Feeding Stamina Leading to Earlier Discharge and Healthier Development

BraimStem Biometrics Inc.

www.brainstembiometrics.com

Sleep disruptions are common among hospitalized patients, particularly in critically ill individuals. For premature babies in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs), maintaining a healthy sleep schedule is vital. Premature infants, who often face survival challenges, allocate approximately 50 minutes of every hour to rest, conserving their limited energy for essential activities like feeding. Unfortunately, many premature infants experience unintentional interruptions to their sleep, caused by eager new mothers seeking bonding moments and busy nurses attending to a ward full of infants. These suboptimal sleep patterns can lead to reduced feeding stamina, prolonged hospital stays by several days or even weeks, and substantial avoidable medical expenses. Premature infants are also prone to day-night reversal and heightened complications due to disrupted sleep patterns.

The challenge lies in discerning whether a premature baby is in deep sleep, active dreaming, or awake, as their eyes are almost always closed. This often results in well-intentioned disruptions from both mothers and nurses. In response to this issue, we have developed a straightforward solution through a small business innovation and research and development program. Our solution allows caregivers to continually monitor the baby's sleep and feeding state and adjust their interactions accordingly. Essentially, we've created a small, adorable "do not disturb" sign, similar to those in hotels, enabling caregivers to synchronize their activities with the premature baby's needs for survival.

You might wonder why existing technology, such as smartwatches or fitness trackers, can't detect the sleep rhythms of premature infants. The answer is simple: these devices are not suitable for the intensive care environment and lack FDA approval. While expensive consumer sleep trackers can provide approximate sleep pattern information for healthy adults at home, they lack the capability to access the deep neural sleep control centers within the brain. Complex, high-performance sleep measurement machines used in hospital sleep laboratories can read brain sleep waves but are bulky, unwieldy, and expensive. Consequently, they are rarely employed in NICUs, except in cases of seizures or severe brain trauma.

Our company, BrainStem Biometrics, has developed a tiny, unobtrusive eye patch that nurses can place on the outer eyelid of a premature baby. This patch is safe, harmless, and can be worn for extended periods, even when the baby opens their eyes. Combined with cutting-edge neuroscience and computer programming, this small adhesive patch allows us to access the intricate neural sleep circuits within the baby's brainstem. As a result, we can convert the detected brain signals into a simple "do not disturb" display panel that parents and nurses can use to determine the optimal time for their activities. We've condensed complex neuroscience into a practical and invaluable tool that has the potential to significantly improve the health and well-being of premature infants, helping them transition home earlier and grow stronger for the life that awaits them. At BrainStem Biometrics, we believe this is a noble and worthwhile endeavor.
